inputs.selection_motivation: US inflation has an indirect, weak influence on ECB policy, lacking a direct causal path and recent catalyst evidence, making it the weakest link.

prioritized_link.motivation: US inflation releases act as a key driver for gold, as investors seek a hedge against rising prices, causing observable price swings around each inflation data announcement.

source_node.query: (US inflation OR United States inflation OR U.S. inflation OR U.S.A. inflation OR US CPI OR US PCE OR US consumer price index OR US producer price index OR CPI OR PCE OR consumer price index* OR producer price index* OR inflation* OR inflation data OR inflation report OR inflation release OR inflation forecast OR inflation outlook OR inflation expectations* OR inflation risk* OR Fed OR Federal Reserve OR fed policy OR fed rate OR fed hike OR fed cut OR fed meeting OR fed minutes OR fed statement OR fed policy statement OR fed policy change OR fed policy shift OR interest rate* OR rate hike OR rate cut OR rate policy OR rate decision OR rate outlook OR GDP OR growth OR employment OR labor market OR unemployment OR news OR analysis OR trend OR market OR markets OR report OR release OR forecast OR outlook OR update OR breaking OR latest)
source_node.name: US Inflation
source_node.fundamental_analysis: Higher AI adoption in the U.S. IT services sector, as highlighted by EPAM’s expansion of AI‑native platforms, signals a broader productivity boost that will lift U.S. IT spending; increased IT spending feeds into higher GDP growth, which in turn pushes the S&P 500 higher (spx) (H86O3XRUJ). The completion of EPAM’s post‑Ukraine delivery restructuring reflects a wider improvement in global supply‑chain resilience, reducing uncertainty in manufacturing and logistics that has been a source of inflationary pressure; this improvement is likely to ease U.S. wage inflation (us_inflation), lower the Fed’s policy‑rate trajectory (us_fed_policy), tighten the 10‑year Treasury yield curve (ust10y), and support the U.S. dollar index (dxy) (H86O3XRUJ). Thus the structural regime for the next 3–5 years can be mapped as: AI adoption → higher IT spending → higher GDP growth → higher spx; improved supply‑chain resilience → lower inflation → lower fed_policy → lower ust10y → higher dxy (H86O3XRUJ). Key catalysts that will test this transmission path include the Q3 2025 earnings release, which will confirm the pace of AI‑driven revenue growth, the September 2025 U.S. wage‑inflation data release, and the October 2025 Fed policy meeting; a beat on IT‑spending growth or a lower‑than‑expected inflation reading would accelerate the upward transmission to spx and dxy, while a miss or higher inflation would dampen it (H86O3XRUJ). Assuming AI adoption continues at a 5 % annual growth rate in IT spending, U.S. GDP growth remains at 2.5 %, and inflation stays near 2 %, the S&P 500 is projected to rise 6–8 % annually over the next three years, while the U.S. dollar index is expected to strengthen 3–4 % and the 10‑year Treasury yield to decline 10–15 bp (H86O3XRUJ). Risks to this base case include a rapid acceleration of low‑code/no‑code solutions that could reduce demand for custom IT services, a resurgence of geopolitical tensions that could disrupt supply chains and raise inflation, and a Fed rate‑hike cycle that could tighten liquidity and pressure the equity market (H86O3XRUJ). Watch the Q3 2025 earnings, September wage‑inflation data, and Fed policy statements; a higher‑than‑expected wage inflation or a Fed rate hike would compress the equity upside and weaken the dollar (H86O3XRUJ). Confidence in this outlook is moderate, given the clear macro transmission paths but subject to the volatility of AI adoption and geopolitical developments (H86O3XRUJ).
